title: U.S.-China Summit Produces Little More Than Polite Words, but They Help
content: In a chilly relationship of mutual mistrust, staving off the prospect of a broader conflict between two superpowers counts as progress.

more_info.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and David E. Sanger

title: Pfizer Will Allow Its Covid Pill to Be Made and Sold Cheaply in Poor Countries
content: The company announced a deal that could help significantly expand access to the Covid-19 treatment, but the agreement excludes a number of countries hit hard by the pandemic.

more_info.byline: By Stephanie Nolen and Rebecca Robbins

title: The Worst of Both Worlds: Zooming From the Office
content: Work life for many is in a mushy middle ground, and what’s at stake isn’t just who is getting talked over in meetings. It’s whether flexibility is sustainable, even with all the benefits it confers.

title: Racial Equity in Infrastructure, a U.S. Goal, Is Left to States
content: The decision about how to spend the money falls largely to state governments, raising questions about whether the package can live up to its ambition.

more_info.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Madeleine Ngo

title: Biden Got His Bipartisan Win. Now, Reality Sets In.
content: President Biden, who is facing low approval ratings, hopes the infrastructure bill will help him project sustained progress in confronting a surge in inflation and growing alarm about the midterm elections.

title: Blue-Chip Art From Bitter Macklowe Divorce Brings $676 Million at Sotheby’s
content: A Sotheby’s executive called the court-ordered sale on Monday night “the most valuable single-owner auction ever staged.”

title: What’s the Future of Outdoor Dining in New York?
content: As the city debates a plan to make outdoor dining permanent, vocal opposition is growing in affluent, restaurant-rich neighborhoods like the West Village.

title: Skiing Hut-to-Hut in the Maine Wilderness
content: An effort to conserve the state’s 100 Mile Wilderness has created one of the best lodge-to-lodge cross-country ski routes in the United States.

title: How to Ski Smarter in the Age of Multi-Mountain Passes
content: Resort companies’ focus on season passes has changed skiing, but savvy skiers can dodge the crowds and reap the benefits.

title: Before Buying Lift Tickets, Get Your Skis
content: Rising demand and supply shortages suggest you rent or buy before the snow flies.

title: What to Expect as Ski Areas Head Into Another Pandemic Season
content: With fewer Covid protocols at many resorts, guests can expect shorter lift lines and less outdoor masking. But policies differ, depending on the area, so know before you go.

title: How to Make Your Thanksgiving Dinner Less Boring
content: Samin Nosrat will say it: Every year, the meal is a lot of the same. Here are five ways she adds brightness, crunch, freshness and flavor.

title: In Another Trump Book, a Journalist’s Belated Awareness Steals the Show
content: “Betrayal,” by Jonathan Karl, is a record of Trump’s last year in office — and of a seasoned White House correspondent’s attempt to understand it.

des_facet: Betrayal: The Final Act of the Trump Show (Book)

title: A Colleague Had Covid. Should Our Supervisor Have Told Us?
content: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on balancing safety and medical-privacy concerns in the workplace — and how best to persuade a friend to get vaccinated.

title: The Absurd Side of the Social Justice Industry
content: Substantive change is hard. Telling people how to talk is easy.

title: ‘Everyone’s a Suspect.’ Six Former Israeli Soldiers Speak on Their Time in Hebron.
content: The director Rona Segal learned filmmaking in the Israeli army. Now she turns the camera on her fellow soldiers.

title: Democratic Socialists Need to Take a Hard Look in the Mirror
content: Our beliefs just might not be as popular as we like to think they are.

title: Forget Amazon. The Best Gifts Are Closer Than You Think.
content: It’s time to revive the tradition of puttering about in our favorite shops, looking for something that would make a loved one’s eyes light up.

content: Many journalists were too eager to prove what they thought they already knew about Trump.

content: Broad but shallow antiracism talk isn’t enough to hold on to Asian American support.

content: A historian of the white power movement discusses Jan. 6, Tucker Carlson and the threat of politically motivated violence.

content: Without U.S. and Chinese willingness to enter a clear dialogue, the results could be catastrophic.

content: The future of the virus — and violence — in America.

content: Companies use market power to suppress wages as well as to raise prices. The government is finally paying attention.

content: Family leave should be a right, not a privilege.

content: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

title: The 10 Best Books of 2021: A Virtual Event Announcing Our List
content: On Nov. 30, Times subscribers will be the first to find out what made this year’s 10 Best Books list from editors of The Book Review and a guest, Lena Waithe.

title: Will an Island in Indonesia Become a New Frontier in the Space Race?

content: Jury selection is set to begin on Tuesday following a flurry of motions that began to bring the scope of the hotly anticipated trial into focus.

title: The Police Fatally Shot a Young Girl. Two Teenagers Are Charged With Murder.
content: After two teenage boys exchanged gunfire outside a football game in a Philadelphia suburb, the police opened fire and killed an 8-year-old girl. Now the teenagers are charged with a crime.

title: U.S. Allies Drive Much of World’s Democratic Decline, Data Shows
content: Washington-aligned countries backslid at nearly double the rate of non-allies, data shows, complicating long-held assumptions about American influence.

title: Lawyers Offer Dueling Narratives in Closing Arguments of Rittenhouse Trial
content: The jury will begin deliberating on Tuesday. The prosecution says Kyle Rittenhouse shot three men after instigating the shootings, while his lawyers say he was defending himself.

more_info.byline: By Julie Bosman, Dan Hinkel and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

title: 6 Teens Shot at Park in Aurora, Police Say
content: The injured, all students at Aurora Central High School in Colorado, were shot at nearby Nome Park. They range in age from 14 to 18.

title: 2 Explosions Hit Ugandan Capital
content: Witnesses said there was a blast near a police station and another near Parliament. At least 24 people have been hospitalized.

title: Hundreds Rescued After Landslides Pummel British Columbia
content: Helicopter search crews rescued people who had been trapped in their cars along highways. Heavy rainfall extended into nearby Washington State.

title: Alex Jones Loses by Default in Remaining Sandy Hook Defamation Suits
content: A Connecticut judge’s ruling against the Infowars host combines with decisions in Texas to grant a clean sweep for the families of 10 shooting victims.

title: Unauthorized Migration Across the Mexico-U.S. Border Slips
content: Border crossings declined for the third consecutive month in October, but thousands of Haitians and other migrants were waiting in Mexico, hoping to head north.

title: Two Journalists Arrested as India Cracks Down on Media
content: Faced with sectarian violence in the country’s northeast, the government has responded by disputing reports on the clashes and punishing those who covered them.

more_info.byline: By Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar

title: College Student Charged in Arson at Texas Synagogue
content: Security footage of the attack on Halloween night showed the man carrying a five-gallon fuel jug and a roll of toilet paper to the synagogue’s entrance, the F.B.I. said.

title: Jeanna de Waal Has Already Forgotten About That ‘Diana’ Film
content: The Netflix version of Broadway’s “Diana, the Musical” landed with a thud. But it got people talking. Now the show’s lead actress is staying positive ahead of opening night.

title: Baseball Gets Another Chance to Honor a Legend
content: Minnie Miñoso was a pioneering Black Latino star in the 1950s whose greatness and impact have been overlooked by Hall of Famer voters. That may finally change.

title: In the Fight Against Climate Change, Young Voices Speak Out
content: Five participants in a Generation Climate program convened by The New York Times gave us their thoughts on the issues, why they became involved and what steps make a difference.

title: Seth Meyers: Steve Bannon Fancies Himself to Be Logan Roy
content: Meyers said Bannon was more like “a coked-up flunky who would get hired to help cousin Greg shred some documents and accidentally screw it up.”
